div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

AMATEUR WORK, CAMERA REPAIRS, ETC.
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER Editor and M . SELLING
THE JEWS AT ASSOUAN
div.p: Some Aramaic papyri have just been publish od which shed most interesting light on a very old Jewish wettlement at Ao . In the spring of 1904, Mr. Robert Mond, Hon. Secre tary of the Davy Parady Research Laboratory (Royal Institution), acquired certain Aramaie papyri which had been found near Assouan, There have just been edited by Professor Sayee and Mr. A E Cowley, together with other paperi acquired by Lady William Cecil and by the Bodleian Library, and form one of the most important discoveries that Aramaic epigraphy has yet produced. Through the munificence of Mr. Mond, they have been published in the completest possible manner with bibliographical information by Mr. Seymour de Rioci, and Exyptological notes by Professor Spiegelberg. Professor Sayee himself contributes a valuable introduction, whilst Mr. Cowley has undertaken the wearinome task of deciphering the pepyri, and has given full philological and exegetical notes and glossaries The papyri have been photographed and repro doend with entire
in every respect the critical Apparatus is all that could possibly be desired.

These papyri afford the proof that some time After the disastrous murder of Gedaliah, the governor whom Nebuchadnesar had set over Palestine, colony of Jews had made their way to Asian or Byene, the southern end of Egypt, and had settled down into trading communities. The evidence seems to show that they refrained from intermarrying with Egyp tian, although exceptions are certainly found,

when a widow.lady named Mibtahyah confidence of Yahweh]) marre an Exyp tian whose name showed him to be a devotee of the god Horus. Again, it is extremely in teresting to find references to the shrine of the god Yahy, by whose name oaths are adminis tered. It is obvious, therefore, that the Jews enjoyed religious freedom. Further, the term "Jew" (yftidl) actually secure and it is curious that in some cases the individuals in other papyrare termed Armas. Profusoe Sayon, in the course of his excellent preliminary remarks, explains the interchanges due to the fact that they spoke Aramaic, then the official language of the government in Egypt also throughout the western half of the Persisa empire The Jewish seribes," he observes, cepted and employed the term just readily as the series of say other nationality, evidently regarding their fellow countrymenas merely division of the Are macan family." The Jewish coloniste were not true cities like the native Exyptian, and the descriptive terms applied to them-enfor tanately the phrasing is of obere interpretation-hos angested that they were in a ponition similar to that of the Roman "clienta
The papyri deal with legal affair and hence contain numerous proper natten. We meet with

considerable number which are obviously Jewish: Ethan, Gedaliah, Gemariah, Haggai, Hodaviah, Inish, Jesaniah, Malchish Menahem, Meballam, Nathan,etc. are familiar to everyone There are other name which cannot be exactly paralleled but are unmistakably of Hebrew type, As we found to be the one with the contract-tableta found by the expedition of the University of Pennsylvania to Nippur, there is

considerable mixture of population. Some of the names are undebtedly of Persins origin, uthers are certainly Babylonian; even Arabian namen may be sospected. Egypt was evidently s mopolitan twenty five centuries ago as it is now.

The Jews in that old settlement at Asuan were much interested in land and it is interesting to observe that papyri, with one exception, deal with property in Yeb (Elephantine) in which this little colony of Jews is concerned. The leading spirit is Mahniah (op. Jer, Exii, 12). the son of Yadonish (ep. Yadon, Neh, lil,7) who comes to an agreement with Koniyah, the son of Zadok, respecting a gateway and wall which extends from the southern end of Koniyah's house to the house of Zechariah, the son of Nathan. There are the neighbours of Mahnish to the north, while to the weat lim the street (with the gateway) which separate the house of the two parties from that of an Egyptian milor.

Se time after this Mahaiah M m . moned by his neighbour on the south, Dargus (apparently a Persian), who had laid claim to the ground which intervened. But Mahniah and worn by Yahu the god' and had justified his right, and contract of the year 466 B.C. is Daryman's dood of renunciation. Six years clape and we find that Mahniah has given nin daughter Mittah-yahin marriage to Jens miah, the son of Uriah, his extern neighbour, Hoendows her with the land of one house thirteen cabite by seven with the ringrod. It is no other than the property which Dargman had claimed, and whilst one papyrus ontains the deed which Mahaiah gave his son-in-law, the other is for the daughter, and in it he hands her Dergman's deed of renuncia tion with the advice "Do thoa keep possession of it. If tomorrow or any later day Dergman or his son shall bring an action concerning this bo , produce this dead, and institute an action against him there with."
Thirteen year later, in 446BC, Mahaiah make over to his daughter the house property which he had bought from Moshullem, son of

secur, together with the deed me. It lay to the cost of their houses and was bounded on the south by the house of Yor), son of Penuliah, on the cast by that of Gadol, son of Hombre, and the street, to the north lay the shrined the god Yahu, whilst to the went lived the son of Palto, the priest of an it would appear) certain Bryptian gods In A contract of the year 440 we find Mibtah-yah coming to an agreement with PP, son of Pall, the builder, apparent lly over materials which she had applied for it building. It is noteworthy that the Jewem ww.ars in court by the eyptian godde Bati.
There are numerous points upon which one llis tempted to calarga bat perhape enough has

been said to demonstrate the very great importance of the papyrinot merely for the philologist, but for the biblical student. It is very real gain to be able to obtain some idea of the conditions under which the Jews lived in the fifth century, and there most welcome finde throw much light upon the life and custom of fifth-century Judaism. For we may not unreasonably expect that the evidence which is gradually being collected, whether in Egyp or in Babylonia, will enable us to understand the internal conditions in Palestine itsell, and the mere fact that there we documents have come to light inspire the hope that other popyri, perhape of more vitali portano, may yet le discovered in the near future

div.head: Public Health Dept.
div.p: Drs. George Sarafidis, Panayotis Kapobassi, and Arsen have been authorised to practise in Egypt.

div.head: Khedivial Opera House.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has approved the credit of L.E 6,000 for the preliminary works in connection with the building of the new opera-bouse in Cairo.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin records two cases and two deaths at Baharia, one case at Akhmin, one case and one death at Beni Mazar, and one case at Deshneh.

div.head: New Telegraph LIne.
div.p: The Telegraph Department has decided to create a new telegrapbic line between Assouan and Wady Halfa. The cost of the undertaking is estimated at L.E. 1,500.

div.head: Ivory Auotione.
div.p: The following quantities have arrived in London for the quarterly sales, April 23: Egyptian, 3 tons ; Abyssinian, 8 tons ; Esst Indian, 2 tons. Deliveries since January auctions 32, tons.

div.head: The Automobile Club.
div.p: This Cairo club is organising a motor car gymkhans for the 8th proxo, at the "Egyptian Trotter" at Shoobra and a ball on the 15th proxo, in order to inaugurate the new club buildings at Kasr el-Nil.

div.head: 'The Egyptian Standard."
div.p: Mustaphs Pasha Kamel's new European organs, "L'Etendard Egyptien" and the "Egyptian Standard," will appear in Cairo on Saturday afternoon and Monday morning, respectively. The Pasha will give an "at home" on Saturday afternoon at the Grand Continental Hotel on the occasion of the appearance of the new papers.

div.head: Emancipation of Women
div.p: At the meeting of the Khedivial Geographical Society, which was held at Cairo a few days ago, the appearance of a young Egyptian lady, the danghter of . prominent dative, who attended Abbate Paeba's lecture with her father, was mnoh commented on as a sign of the emancipation of the Egyptian woman. Still, ODP swallow does not make a summer.

div.head: Mutiny on Board
div.p: The German 8.8. Hermann Merzell, bound for Marseilles from Reanion with a cargo of sogar, left Port Said yesterday. Shortly after wards, however, a matiny broke oat on boart! and the captain was compelled to retorn in order to land the delinqnents. Order was only restored on board by the intervention of the port police.

div.head: Egyptian Institute.
div.p: A meeting of the Egyptian Institute will be held in Cairo on Monday next at 5 p.m.; when the following papers will be read :M. Dimitracopoulos. 'Le Mystère de la vie, Btode Puyobopbysique sur les phénomènes de la vie ; M. Galapte, "L: langne e-pagnole en O ient et ses déformations ;" M Piot Bey,
Une plaie de l'Egypte actuelle ;" Prof. Eliot Smith Report on the unrolling of the mom mies of the Kings Siptah, Seti II, Ramsès IV., Rmdr V. and Ramsès VI."

div.head: Zizinia Theatre
div.p: The committee of the Maltere Benevolent Society is to be congratulated on the brilliant 8000888 which attended the performance of "Tosca" given at the Z zipia last night in aid of its funds. Whether artistically, sogially, or financially, no greater success could bave been aobieved. The auditorium was filled with a tasbionable audience, and we bave seldom seen it look prettier than it did last night. The committee had taken considerable psins in the decoration of the theatre, and the result attained with Alwers and flags was pleasing in the extreme. Each box was provided with artistio bouquets, and among the ocenpants of these were Mr. B. B. Goold, I. 8. O., H. B. M's Consol-General (ander whose patronage the performance was placed) and Mrs. Goald, HE. the Sub Governor, accompanied by Benedaoci Bey, eto. As we have said, the performance was an entire 8000088, and reflected the great at credit on all concernet. After the sezond aot, Big, Alfredo Costa (Baron Sosrpia) and Signa. Berlendi (Toso) came in for a tremendous ovation, and were greeted with a *bower of flwers, while a happy innovation was the setting free of a number of snow-white doves, some of which found their way to the stage and ware captared by the delighted artistes.

Admiral Nowell Jmon, who is staying at the Cataract Hotel, Amos, colebrated bis birthday there last week. He w born in 1885 and is the grandson of an admiral. At the age of twelve he joined H.M.8. Dragon

paddlewheel steam frigate, and was soon oot At Lisbon with the Channel Pleat How Rotive service in the Baltie dering the wa Tin the Cris , and in the Indian Mutiny won the V.C. It w at Lacknow, and, it being De sary to locate the enemy's exact position, Bir William Peel called for a volunteer to climba neighbouring palm tree. Young Salmon me forward, although it was almost certain death, and elambered up the tree, bring was while the target for bedre til bolleta tearing away the leaves and piercing even portion of his clothing. He was able wever, to make a full report, thoa gaining not only tba soroll doneration but also promotion, Ha beld the rank of minder at the early Age of twenty-three. He has since been in command at Portant and on the Chin. l Cape of Good Hope, and West Africa atatiana In 1999 he became Admiral of the Pleat, and bis retirement took place two years ago.

div.head: THE OASIS OF SIWA
A KHEDIVIAL VISIT
div.p: (Continued from yesterday.) It was pouring with rain when we reached Goaiferi, and even on the very morning when the Oravan started on ite pilgrimage to the rajoel sanetaaria, Japiter bad not favograd 08 with better weather. I hope to report on some fatore D ion about the highly interest ing geolog asl condition of the stratob of land to which we were coming, where the rooks appear in hoge boulders often many metres are. The nomade had written on these fig-stones their way marks in order that the traveller should not long himself, just as they had lo greeted pyramida of stone, 80 oalloi Allam, between one halting place and another, Bedouin tents surrounded by the loat sigos of cultivated soil beosme very soaroo. There is yet another more solema pietara and way.

ark 0.0 now and again. Oar byen raat on a small nomadio graveyard: small beaps of earth cloned in by atoes, with Aying banners. The horse proceed very - stendily and nood sional resta. All the more we admire the camels, walking at a qaiet regular paos. How many times have the merits of this noble and indispensable animal beon sang by poeta, and this in all justice, for without its are step trending firmly on any voil, the journey in these parts could not be socomplished. It rooms to us today incosveivable that there should have been a time when no "ship of the desert crossed Lybis, and when Herodoth'. MATAMORes an i Sallast's Iagartha Warriors orood these roads without osmols. It was Antiochos who, at the battle of Magasin, introdased them to the civilisd world and in the fourth cautary they are already 40 nomerous in the North of Africs that the Prince of Tripoli could claim the large som ber of 4000 transport Amela from the Laptiers.
Three wella lie on the road at an equal fistance of two hours from each other Bir G ba, Bir Gramath, and Bir Hift. A wall chain of hills to the east of Br Gre
sett is olled by the Bodonia: Djabal Tarot. Hare and there the barres stone desert irer place to patches of green shrabs and

oy plants whose swaet seat fills the spring air. Mach lite and animation reiga amongst tha foor gronps of the caravan. The leading sheikh Parag, ela ia bis Morocco,burscose, rides at the head, th, Khediva follows in his Light coash Broorted by fifteen men of his body guard. Next come the bired animals of the Bedouins; M od Aboa Goalaa follows them and his strong camels soon got ap to the others. Ridiag and transport camels wind op the carAVAD. Could I over forget the friends who, perched on horses or riding camels, shorten the long day's ride, consisting of twelve boars, with their songs and fairy talee! It was a bever-to-bo-forgotten sight, when Abmet Aboa Belter, "Pather of the Hoe" alias Tabbsch Pash, i.e, chief cook, mounted his patient ateed, asistei by six trong arms and role to th: Aumoniam. What attracted me next was Mahmood,

Pather of the Ridiag Camelio whom no one recognizid the former slave-desler. While listening to bis stories from Wadai, Da for, or the Sudan, one noticed that an old fire kindled in bis eyes, and one saw in him ono more the kidnapper who made off with many a prize simply by holding the thumb of his victim in his mooth.

After ride of eight bours we reached Dantis, "The Chorobe, amidst sunshine And blue skies. Long before the table moon tains had bsen visible, rising bigh in the Best and West from the plateau and forming stop descents down to the well lyingiu the centre of the land surrounded by bills.

Two comes in the North Baat bear strong weather-beaten, ruined walls, and also dowo at the well the above mentioned Walia Oan be traced. Kansia itselt is a pase, the inmediate continuation of the Bustern and Western chains, sporadically shaped, and the lower parta rich in oyster-bod, star fiab, abella, and corals. He who has so it Ouce never Horgeta the character of the soil and would be able wherever be came from, to find bis way. This apot, which is not to be mistakes for the Ruel Kaunis, is mystically envelop od liko all Ancient relios.
The camp lit up by the setting son offered an incomparable spectacle, soldiers on horse

MR. DICEY'S ACCURACY To The Edrror of the EarPTIAN GARETTE."

Sir, -la the Egyptian Garette" of last Welnesday I noticed a letter dealing with the remarkable discrepanci between Mr. Dicey'argom sata in "The Egypt of the Pa ture" and recent Oistribution by that gentlemen to the Day Telegraph," and as no reply hua yot appesred I priamo your correspondent's animadversions are ananswers ble. I shoald, however, like to point out that the one and only effort at constrativa eriticism made by the author of "The Beypt of the Facore" repose: on a procedent which in atterly mialading and which is especially wischievous because it may lead some ignorant natives, who read the book, to form totally erroneons iden. I may state that I have not the slightest anim against Mr. Dicey or his work, and I thoroughly enj vyed reading the two last obapters of his latest book, which contain a considerable amount of Amor ing criticism and which, M farm I can judge, for the raison dare of the work, M the first five chapters are more examples of book making. The book, how iver, is only interesting for its destructive oriticien. Bat the author tightly judges that he is logically alled upon to ask, at some sort of policy. which will be an improvement on Lord Cromer's and this is the result. He remarks:

"If I am mked what I should propas as alternative, I should recommand the aystem which has been adopted in the native States of Iadis by Bagland, ia Tania and Algeria by Prance, and in Bonis and the tragovios by Autris, and adopted with 1000 . The fondamental principles of this system may be stated briefly as follows. Sapreme authority abould be vested in the heads of the representative of the Protecting Pomor, whether ho may be called Resident, Governor, or Consal General. Tumeaministrators should be clearly I given to understand that they would be allowed

considerable latitude in the discharge of their anctions, and that thy would not be called to scoot if their als gistration should be considered some diffrently from th: view ontertained by the Protesting Power, bat that if any gross Sandal or abans should con during their administration they would be forth with dismissed or, if necessary, severely panished by the representative of the Protesto rate. To work on the details of such a system must be the work of the Rsident, and this cah only be done by the men on the spot. All I am concerned with iaita broad principle"

He remarks: "L'Algérie nous offre le spectacle d'en pays qu'on a tenté de plaes dans le lit de Procaste d'an organisme politie qne et administratif importé da debore et en opposition avec ses besoins," and he declare: that Tania waited for five or six years before being able to begin the construction of its sesond ay tem of railway which she had to wake at her owa expanse. He praises the Bogli b system of decentralisatfon , Ierita le retarde entrat per la centrali T son Paris de toute les faire de quelque importanon." The administration of Tunin is aminslly in the hands of the Bey, bat aish of his note is inspired or advised by the Praneb Resident. Le démenti est positivament charmant. Per BORD, on offit, n'avait prétenda qa'il s'agirait d'on fait accompli, en d'autres termes que le ospital de £ 400.000 de la Financial Corpora tion of Bgypt était déjà trouvé ou souscrit.

La dividende attribué A l'action ordinaire revient ainsi à 16 sh.at selai de la part de tonda tear à 84, payables à partir da 4 Mana prochain.
L'assemblée n'a pas pris en considération De proposition faite par quelqnes actionnaires tondant à la lignidation immédiate des 166, 318 nations da Orédit Poucier Bgyptien
Le rapport de conseil dit, d'ailleurs, ce qui wait a sajet de des actions:

"La dividende distribué par le Credit Fon cier a 66 d. Pro. 17 par motion pour l'exercice olos lo 81 Octobre 1906. Beadmettant même qa'il 'y ait pas progression dans les affaires de ont étab iseen et pour l'année en cours, ce I qui n'est pas le cas, le dividende u'au sera pas moins d'environ 95 franos par suite de l'appel de Fra. 125 qui vient d'avoir lieu et sur lequel, d'après sa Statata, le Crédit Poncier doit servir un intérêt de 6%. Notre motif étant composé wartout d'action de Crédit Foncier, nos bénéfios sannels angmenteront naturellement avec l'augmentation da dividendo qui sera distribué par le Crédit Poncier."

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
